channel.name: tutorial 04 using local development instead of testnet

messages.content: Would it be possible to have the UI code of tutorial04 following npm link flow instead of testnet? thanks
Where would you like to see `npm link` being used? Or what flow are you referring to?
https://docs.minaprotocol.com/zkapps/how-to-write-a-zkapp-ui

embeds.title: How to Write a zkApp UI | Mina Documentation
embeds.description: Please note that zkApp programmability is not yet available on Mina Mainnet, but

messages.content: I am not entirely sure what is it that you're asking, but i suspect you'd like to interact with a contract that you've built and deployed yourself?

I mean in tutorial 04 we interact with the testnet: https://docs.minaprotocol.com/zkapps/tutorials/zkapp-ui-with-react
We interact with workers, and some elements specific to the testnet example `await zkappWorkerClient.setActiveInstanceToBerkeley();`

So I wanted to know if we could have this UI rewritten according to the local development flow?

embeds.title: Tutorial 4: Building a zkApp UI in the Browser with React | Mina Do...
embeds.description: Please note that zkApp programmability is not yet available on Mina Mainnet, but

messages.content: For local development flow, you'd need to run a 'testnet' locally, a.k.a. sandbox. @Florian should have a link for a local development node setup somewhere. You'd need to set your local Mina's instance graphql endpoint (or other config) that `setActiveInstanceToBerkeley` does. (i am yet to find where is this implemented)
Do you want to spin up your own network?
or just a mocked local instance
local sandbox -> https://github.com/MinaProtocol/mina/tree/develop/scripts/mina-local-network
@Florian mocked instance as in tests does not expose a node graphql endpoint  right? We should figure out if all the methods in snarky are compatible without having a full node with graphql
Because someone might run into using a certain method in their UI, but not in their tests - and that method/code might be trying to call the graphq endpoint
The `LocalBlockchain` should provide you with everything you would need in a live scenario (even more, since some things arent implemented on the `RemoteBlockchain` yet)
But if that helps, we are running e2e tests in SnarkyJS as well https://github.com/o1-labs/snarkyjs/tree/main/tests

embeds.title: snarkyjs/tests at main Â· o1-labs/snarkyjs
embeds.description: Typescript/Javascript framework for zk-SNARKs and zkApps - snarkyjs/tests at main Â· o1-labs/snarkyjs

messages.content:
I'd suggest alternating between the following, depending on if you want to test on a single client locally, or on multiple clients.

Local only (even on UI, not just tests):
https://github.com/o1-labs/snarkyjs/blob/main/tests/artifacts/javascript/on-chain-state-mgmt-zkapp-ui.js#L29

Full sandbox:
https://github.com/MinaProtocol/mina/tree/develop/scripts/mina-local-network
ah yes, that sounds reasonable
```if(environment.testLocally) { ... } else { ... }```
awesome thanks, will try tomorrow

i was also looking into an equivalent of hardhat network or anvil. the sandbox looks promising, though also a tad cumbersome as a regular developer experience.

*ideally* i'd want a single command/tool to run a local mocked network so i can test (a) configuration and deployment, and (b) develop a frontend fully locally.

Hey @brent (basejump), I'd like to understand, what would that give you over the `LocalBlockchain`? To my mind `LocalBlockchain` is a super easy to use replacement of real interactions, for local testing, way simpler than spinning up a full network locally
Maybe what the `LocalBlockchain` is missing is letting you initialize the ledger state from some dumped JSON object, so you get (optional) persistence across tabs / browsers / machines

Does LocalBlockchain run a local graphql endpoint that Auro can use? Maybe I just didnâ€™t see the docs for it. I assumed it was for in-process testing. If so, Iâ€™d just like to wrap that in a command to run via zk-cli
Persistence isnâ€™t needed
no it doesn't run an endpoint and can't be used with Auro
I mean, maybe Iâ€™m just coming with too much of an EVM mindset, but the various EVM tools all have a way to run a local rpc endpoint for development against.
Ganache, Hardhat, Foundry Anvil
Do they also have `LocalBlockchain` equivalents?
I guess the local rpc endpoint is pretty useful for e2e  testing across tools like Auro
I guess a major difference to EVM is that the actual execution for zkApps happens in the browser, not on a node
so we can move more of the testing process into the browser / nodejs
Yes, they all can run a simulated blockchain for testing as well, and that doesnâ€™t open an endpoint.

Could be. Iâ€™m not clear on what this would look like. 

Stepping back, I think what Iâ€™m looking for is a local way to simulate production.
For full stack development

So, is it fair to say that something like local blockchain, which can be easily started up and provides a local graphql endpoint, would provide that simulation.
And that is because we can test with a wallet
Yes, or more generally you can test with any client. You can run scripts against it, use a wallet UI with it, etc.
Frontend devs and dapp builders need some quick way to stand up a mainnet-like environment.
this is all very helpful! I think it shouldn't be that hard to build, will discuss with the team
Cool. Check in with others too! Iâ€™m curious how everyone in the builder program approached there UIs. I had to develop my UI against Berkeley which was arduous.
Because I had to redeploy to Berkeley if I needed to make a change to the contract.
Which in turn required creating and funding a new key pair
(which is why I was asking about zk deploy with a different fee payer)
sounds awful
I created this, feel free to add: https://github.com/o1-labs/snarkyjs/issues/623

embeds.title: Local graphQL endpoint for UI development Â· Issue #623 Â· o1-labs/sn...
embeds.description: Raised by community member in discord IS: When developing a UI, the current flow seems to be to deploy the smart contract to Berkeley, and interact via Auro with the deployed contract. This is an a...
